title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@rstudio.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to expstudy
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to expstudy
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("cb12991/expstudy", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to expstudy
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

what: Experience Study Tools for Analytics and Communications
title: Experience Study Tools for Analytics and Communications
text: goal expstudy provide set tools quickly conduct analysis experience study. Commonly used techniques (actual--expected analysis) generalized streamlined repetitive coding avoided.

title: Experience Study Tools for Analytics and Communications
code: # This package has not yet been submitted to CRAN, however, # you can install the development version from GitHub:  # install.packages('devtools') devtools::install_github('cb12991/expstudy')

title: Experience Study Tools for Analytics and Communications
text: First need dataset can used experience study: Now can convert expstudy object: expstudy object, quick example can shown using compile_results(): compile_results() function combines many expstudy functions produce many summaries. Since nothing potential groupings provided, coompile_results() generate nested list summaries: unformatted summary can used subsequent analysis… …formatted summary can quickly simply inserted report distribute nicely. can review trim summaries want without much effort. also can access formulae used compile_results() fully customize analysis fit needs.
code: library(expstudy) #>  #> Attaching package: 'expstudy' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     aggregate, filter #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, union dataset <- data.frame(   GENDER = sample(c('MALE','FEMALE'), size = 10000, replace = TRUE),   ATTAINED_AGE = sample(     c('Under 40', '40 to 65', '65+'), size = 10000, replace = TRUE   ),   RECORD_YEARSPAN = runif(10000, max = 5),   EXPECTED_DEATHS = runif(10000, max = 5),   ACTUAL_DEATHS = runif(10000, max = 5) ) # Only need to specify which variables correlate to metric variable `actuals`,  # `expecteds`, and `exposures`. `variances` and `keys` are beneficial, but not # required.   es <- expstudy(   data = dataset,   actuals = ACTUAL_DEATHS,   expecteds = EXPECTED_DEATHS,   exposures = RECORD_YEARSPAN ) # We will supply only the dataset and grouping variables to use for the  # summaries to generate a more robust list of results.   results <- compile_results(   expstudy = es,   GENDER,   ATTAINED_AGE ) glimpse(results) #> List of 2 #>  $ UNFORMATTED:List of 2 #>   ..$ METRICS    :List of 4 #>   .. ..$ AGGREGATE tbl_es [2 x 7] (S3: tbl_es/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "metric_vars")=List of 3 #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "metrics_applied")=List of 2 #>   .. ..$ BY ATTAINED_AGE           : tbl_es [3 x 7] (S3: tbl_es/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "metric_vars")=List of 3 #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "metrics_applied")=List of 2 #>   .. ..$ BY GENDER AND ATTAINED_AGE: tbl_es [6 x 8] (S3: tbl_es/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "metric_vars")=List of 3 #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "metrics_applied")=List of 2 #>   ..$ PROPORTIONS:List of 4 #>   .. ..$ AGGREGATE                 : tbl_es [1 x 6] (S3: tbl_es/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "metric_vars")=List of 3 #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "metrics_applied")=List of 2 #>   .. ..$ BY GENDER                 : tbl_es [2 x 7] (S3: tbl_es/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "metric_vars")=List of 3 #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "metrics_applied")=List of 2 #>   .. ..$ BY ATTAINED_AGE           : tbl_es [3 x 7] (S3: tbl_es/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "metric_vars")=List of 3 #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "metrics_applied")=List of 2 #>   .. ..$ BY GENDER AND ATTAINED_AGE: tbl_es [6 x 8] (S3: <dbl> results$FORMATTED$PROPORTIONS$`BY ATTAINED_AGE` #> # A tibble: 3 x 7 #>   ATTAINED_AGE ACTUAL_DEATHS EXPECTED_DEATHS RECORD_YEARSPAN PROP_ACTUAL_DEATHS #> * <chr>        <chr>         <chr> title: Experience Study Tools for Analytics and Communications
text: Please note expstudy project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: Add Credibility Factors — add_credibility
text: Add credibility factors expstudy's expecteds metric variable. credibility calculation uses classical credibility approach also known limited fluctuation partial credibility. approach, credibility factor calculated actuals within \(k\)\ expecteds probability \(p\). Credibility range parameter \(k\) probability level \(p\) set using function arguments .cred_k .cred_p, respectively.

title: Add Credibility Factors — add_credibility
text: expstudy expstudy() .cred_k number within range (0, 1); range parameter credibility equation .cred_p number within range (0, 1); probability parameter credibility equation .cred_nms character vector column names added credibility column. one credibility column created, can distinguish .

title: Add Credibility Factors — add_credibility
text: expstudy added credibility factors.

title: Add Metrics — add_metrics
text: Add commonly used metrics expstudy(). typically grouping variables interest, . following metrics available default use expstudy's metric variables (actuals, expecteds, andexposures). 'act2expec': actuals expecteds (.e., /E ratios) 'act2expos': actuals exposures (.e., average actually observed) 'expec2expos': expecteds exposures (.e., average expected) can also create custom metrics add providing (optionally named) metric formulae.

title: Add Metrics — add_metrics
code: add_metrics(   expstudy,   ...,   .metrics = c("act2expec", "act2expos", "expec2expos"),   .metric_nms = list(act2expec = "ACTUAL_TO_EXPECTED", act2expos = "ACTUAL_TO_EXPOSED",     expec2expos = "EXPECTED_TO_EXPOSED") )

title: Add Metrics — add_metrics
text: expstudy expstudy() ... additional metrics add. Can name-value pairs simply metric's formula. .metrics default methods add; omitted, metrics listed added .metric_nms pairlist .metric names; can character vector expstudy object multiple columns per .metrics argument

title: Add Metrics — add_metrics
text: expstudy object added metrics. See expstudy() additional detail expstudy objects.

title: Add Proportions — add_proportions
text: Add proportions expstudy metric variables. variables can provided via <dynamic-dots> argument proportions wanted well. Proportions sum 100% per group .base_grp_nms provided. .base_grp_nms omitted, proportions sum 100% total.

title: Add Proportions — add_proportions
text: expstudy expstudy() ... columns expstudy metric variables (actuals, expecteds, exposures) generate proportions .base_grp_nms character vector column names use base added proportions .min_ungrpd minimum number non-grouping columns required using .base_grp_nms proportion base

title: Add Proportions — add_proportions
text: expstudy added proportions.

title: Aggregate an expstudy — aggregate
text: Often expstudy needs aggregated according different variables analysis. function provides easy aggregation expstudy metric variables exposures, expected, actuals. Grouping can performed passing variables unnamed arguments. groups specified, grand total expstudy metric variables returned. default, metric variables summed returned. variables can also totaled using .oth_sum_vars specify.

title: Aggregate an expstudy — aggregate
text: expstudy expstudy() ... variables use groups .oth_sum_vars additional variable total. Multiple variables can provided using c().

title: Aggregate an expstudy — aggregate
text: aggregated expstudy.

title: Compile resulting analyses — compile_results
text: streamlined approach, function combines multiple expstudy-package functions generate multiple analyses simultaneously. grouping combinations generated variables passed <dynamic-dots>, analytics created . Resulting output can typical metrics via add_metrics(), proportions via add_proportions(). Default parameters used function, however, can pass additional parameters list corresponding function element via output_args argument. Furthermore, can choose results return unformatted (calculations analysis) formatted (presentation purposes). function meant provide quick results routine analysis. additional -depth analyses make use individual expstudy functions instead.

title: Compile resulting analyses — compile_results
code: compile_results(   expstudy,   ...,   output = c("metrics", "proportions"),   output_args = list(metrics = NULL, proportions = NULL),   output_format = c("unformatted", "formatted") )

title: Compile resulting analyses — compile_results
text: expstudy expstudy() ... variables generate grouped analyses. combinations variables provided generated used groups results. output type result output (.e., metrics proportions). omitted, generated returned list. output_args additional arguments pass add_metrics() add_proportions(). omitted, default parameters used functions. output_format resulting output format. omitted, generated returned list.

title: Compile resulting analyses — compile_results
text: (potentially nested) list resulting analysis according arguments passed function.

title: Create an expstudy object — expstudy
code: expstudy(data, actuals, expecteds, exposures, variances = NULL, keys = NULL)

title: Create an expstudy object — expstudy
text: data dataset experience study. Can kind organized data (e.g., base::data.frame(), tibble::tibble(), etc.) must able converted data.table::data.table(). actuals observed variable (variables) within experience study (e.g., actual lapse counts lapse study). expecteds expected variable (variables) within experience study (e.g., actual deaths mortality study). exposures exposure variable (variables) within experience study. time records spans years (within (0, 1) records covering less year). variances variance variable (variables) within experience study. may available studies, thus can omitted. Variance used credibility calculations. keys variables uniquely describe every record within experience study. typically policy number measure time, annual monthly duration. Can omitted, providing enables quicker binary searches within dtplyr::lazy_dt(). information, refer data.table vignette: vignette('datatable-keys-fast-subset', package = 'data.table').

title: tbl_es class — tbl_es-class
text: tbl_es class subclass dtplyr::lazy_dt() created order store attributes experience studies. colloquial term 'expstudy' refers lazy_dt() tbl_es subclass.

title: tbl_es class — tbl_es-class
text: Attributes store variable names used key metric calculations: actuals: observed variable (variables) within experience study (e.g., actual lapse counts lapse study). expecteds: expected variable (variables) within experience study (e.g., expected number deaths mortality study). exposures: exposure variable (variables) within experience study. time records spans years (within (0, 1) records covering less year). variances: optional, variance variable (variables) within experience study. may available studies, thus can omitted. Variance used credibility metric. additional (optional) keys attribute can uniquely describe every record within experience study. typically policy number measure time, annual monthly duration. Can omitted, providing enables quicker binary searches within dtplyr::lazy_dt(). information, refer data.table vignette: vignette('datatable-keys-fast-subset', package = 'data.table').

title: tbl_es class — tbl_es-class
text: tbl_es behaves dtplyr::lazy_dt() differing retaining attributes listed . saves time routine, repetitive coding, leading increased time analysis.

title: Tidy eval helpers — tidyeval
text: page lists tidy eval tools reexported package rlang. learn using tidy eval scripts packages high level, see dplyr programming vignette ggplot2 packages vignette. Metaprogramming section Advanced R may also useful deeper dive. tidy eval operators {{, !!, !!! syntactic constructs specially interpreted tidy eval functions. mostly need {{, !! !!! advanced operators use simple cases. curly-curly operator {{ allows tunnel data-variables passed function arguments inside tidy eval functions. {{ designed individual arguments. pass multiple arguments contained dots, use ... normal way. enquo() enquos() delay execution one several function arguments. former returns single expression, latter returns list expressions. defused, expressions longer evaluate . must injected back evaluation context !! (single expression) !!! (list expressions). simple case, code equivalent usage {{ ... . Defusing enquo() enquos() needed complex cases, instance need inspect modify expressions way. .data pronoun object represents current slice data. variable name string, use .data pronoun subset variable [[. Another tidy eval operator :=. makes possible use glue curly-curly syntax LHS =. technical reasons, R language support complex expressions left =, use := workaround. Many tidy eval functions like dplyr::mutate() dplyr::summarise() give automatic name unnamed inputs. need create sort automatic names , use as_label(). instance, glue-tunnelling syntax can reproduced manually : Expressions defused enquo() (tunnelled {{) need simple column names, can arbitrarily complex. as_label() handles cases gracefully. code assumes simple column name, use as_name() instead. safer throws error input name expected.
code: my_function <- function(data, var, ...) {   data %>%     group_by(...) %>%     summarise(mean = mean({{ var }})) } my_function <- function(data, var, ...) {   # Defuse   var <- enquo(var)   dots <- enquos(...)    # Inject   data %>%     group_by(!!!dots) %>%     summarise(mean = mean(!!var)) } my_var <- "disp" mtcars %>% summarise(mean = mean(.data[[my_var]])) my_function <- function(data, var, suffix = "foo") {   # Use `{{` to tunnel function arguments and the usual glue   # operator `{` to interpolate plain strings.   data %>%     summarise("{{ var }}_mean_{suffix}" := mean({{ var }})) } my_function <- function(data, var, suffix = "foo") {   var <- enquo(var)   prefix <- as_label(var)   data %>%     summarise("{prefix}_mean_{suffix}" := mean(!!var)) }
